storyContent.tagHTML: In the city of Räjgrihi lived a wealthy merchant whose handsome and intelligent son was named Jambu. Though engaged to eight women from respected families, Jambu's life took a different course after hearing a sermon by Ganadhar Sudharmä-swämi. The sermon inspired in him a profound sense of detachment, and he declared his intention to become a monk.

His parents and the families of his eight fiancées were dismayed. They pleaded with him, but Jambu was firm. As a last resort, they begged him to at least go through with the wedding, hoping married life would change his mind. Jambu agreed, but on one condition: he would renounce the world the very next day.

Prabhav was captivated. He was struck by the irony of risking his life to steal wealth from a man who was willingly giving it all away. By the end of the night, not only had Jambu convinced his eight wives to renounce the world with him, but Prabhav and his 500 followers were also inspired to give up their lives of crime and become disciples.

The next morning, the city was stunned. In a spectacular procession, Jambu, his eight wives, his parents, the parents of his eight wives, Prabhav, and his 500 followers—a total of 528 people—all went to Sudharmä-swämi to take Dikshä. Jambu became Sudharmä-swämi's chief disciple.

Jambuswämi studied diligently and became the next head of the Jain order after Sudharmä-swämi. He eventually attained Keval-jnän and is known as the last Kevali (omniscient being) of our current time cycle. He attained Nirväna at the age of 80.

events.title: A Noble Son
events.description: Jambu is born to the wealthy merchant Rushabhadatt and his wife Dhärini in Räjgrihi.

events.title: A Life-Changing Sermon
events.description: After hearing a sermon by Sudharmä-swämi, the young Jambu decides he must renounce the world.

events.title: The Wedding Condition
events.description: Pressured by his family, Jambu agrees to marry his eight fiancées on the condition that he can become a monk the very next day.

events.title: An Unexpected Sermon
events.description: Instead of celebrating, Jambu spends his wedding night explaining the path of renunciation to his eight wives.

events.title: The Listening Thief
events.description: A master burglar named Prabhav, there to steal treasure, overhears Jambu's sermon and is deeply moved.

events.title: A Mass Conversion
events.description: By morning, Jambu has inspired his eight wives, Prabhav, and Prabhav's 500 followers to all renounce the world with him.

events.title: The Great Renunciation
events.description: A total of 528 people, inspired by Jambu, renounce their worldly lives and become disciples of Sudharmä-swämi.

events.title: Head of the Order
events.description: Jambuswämi becomes Sudharmä-swämi's chief disciple and eventually succeeds him as the head of the Jain Sangh.

events.title: The Final Kevali
events.description: Jambuswämi attains Keval-jnän and becomes the last omniscient being of the current Avasarpini era. He attains Nirväna at age 80.

charactersData.name: Kevali Jambuswämi
charactersData.description: The chief disciple of Sudharmä-swämi and the last human being to achieve Keval-jnän (omniscience) in our current time cycle. His conviction was so powerful that he inspired over 500 people, including a master thief, to renounce the world on his wedding day.

charactersData.name: Prabhav, the Burglar
charactersData.description: A former prince who became a master thief. He came to Jambu's palace to steal but was transformed by his sermon, giving up a life of crime for a life of spiritual pursuit.

charactersData.name: The Eight Wives
charactersData.description: The eight women Jambu married on his wedding day. Instead of enjoying worldly pleasures, they were inspired by their husband's wisdom and chose to renounce the world alongside him.

charactersData.name: Ganadhar Sudharmä-swämi
charactersData.description: Jambuswämi's guru. His sermon was the catalyst for Jambu's decision to renounce, and he accepted Jambu and all his followers into the monastic order.

quizData.question: What event inspired Jambu to renounce his worldly life?
quizData.answer: Listening to a sermon by Sudharmä-swämi.

quizData.question: How many women was Jambu engaged to marry?
What condition did Jambu make in order to agree to the wedding?
quizData.answer: That he would become a monk the day after his marriage.

quizData.question: Who unexpectedly overheard Jambu's sermon to his wives on his wedding night?
quizData.answer: A famous burglar named Prabhav and his 500 followers.

quizData.question: What was Prabhav's original reason for being in Jambu's palace?
quizData.answer: To steal the valuable wedding treasures.

quizData.question: What was the total number of people who renounced the world with Jambu the next day?
quizData.answer: 528 people (Jambu, his 8 wives, his parents, his wives' 16 parents, Prabhav, and Prabhav's 500 followers).

quizData.question: After Sudharmä-swämi, who became the head of the Jain religious order?
What is Jambuswämi's most significant distinction in Jain cosmology?
quizData.answer: He was the last Kevali (omniscient being) of the current Avasarpini time cycle.

quizData.question: At what age did Jambuswämi attain Nirväna?
Who was Prabhav before he became a thief?
quizData.answer: He was the prince of a neighboring city named Vindhya.

quizData.question: What special skills did Prabhav possess as a burglar?
quizData.answer: He could put anyone into a deep sleep and could break any lock.

quizData.question: Besides Jambu and his wives, who else from their families renounced the world?
quizData.answer: Jambu's parents and the parents of all eight of his wives.

quizData.question: The dialogues between which two individuals make up a large part of the Jain scriptures (Ägams)?

children.name: Agrees to Marry for One Day
The Last Omniscient of the Era

graphicsData.title: The Wedding Agreement
graphicsData.description: Pressured by his family, a resolved Jambu agrees to marry his eight fiancées, but only if he can become a monk the very next day.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young man (Jambu) speaking calmly to his concerned parents.

graphicsData.title: The Thief in the Shadows
graphicsData.description: As Jambu preaches to his wives, the master burglar Prabhav listens from a doorway, his plan to steal forgotten as he is captivated by the words of truth.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A thief hiding in the shadows of a palace, listening intently to a conversation.

graphicsData.title: A Change of Heart
graphicsData.description: Inspired by Jambu's words, Prabhav tells his 500 followers that he is giving up his life of crime, and they all agree to follow him on the new path.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A thief chief talking to his large group of followers, who look surprised and interested.

graphicsData.title: The Great Procession
graphicsData.description: The next morning, an incredible procession of 528 people—including Jambu, his wives, their families, and the former thieves—walks through the city to renounce the world.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A large crowd of people from all walks of life walking together on a spiritual path.

graphicsData.title: Accepting Discipleship
graphicsData.description: Jambu bows before his guru, Sudharmä-swämi, formally becoming his disciple and beginning his journey as a monk.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young man (Jambu) bowing at the feet of an elder monk (Sudharmä-swämi).

graphicsData.title: The Last Omniscient
graphicsData.description: As the last Kevali of the era, Jambuswämi represents the end of an age of enlightenment, a final beacon of perfect knowledge before a period of decline.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A single enlightened monk meditating, symbolizing the end of an era.
